item.title: Presentable Categories
item.description: This note reviews the basic theory of presentable categories. We focus on κ-compact objects, Ind-completions, accessible categories, and their role in organizing large categories via filtered colimits.

item.title: Presentable n-Categories
item.description: This note introduces the notion of presentable n-categories.

item.title: Basic Concepts on Higher Algebra
item.description: This note introduces algebraic patterns and Segal objects, develops operads over algebraic patterns, and studies $\mathcal{O}$-monoidal categories together with $\mathcal{O}$-algebras in the Cartesian setting.

item.title: Stefanich Rings
item.description: This note discuss the colimit of the sequence \[ \mathsf{CAlg}(1\mathsf{Pr}) \hookrightarrow \mathsf{CAlg}(2\mathsf{Pr}) \hookrightarrow \cdots \hookrightarrow \mathsf{CAlg}(n\mathsf{Pr}) \hookrightarrow \cdots . \] in $1\mathsf{Pr}$, and discuss the $n$-affine, $n$-proper, $n$-suave and $n$-prim maps.

item.title: Everything Becomes Affine Under Sufficient Categorification
item.description: This note constructs the six-functor formalism on \(n\mathsf{Pr}_{(-)}\), shows that it is sheafy with respect to fpqc topology, and then extends the theory from affine schemes of derived rings to stacks.

item.title: Playbook
item.description: Principles, allocation bands, and execution rules for my long-term investing.

item.title: Spectral Sequences as Bookkeeping, Not Structure
item.description: In derived settings, many classical comparisons between Čech and sheaf cohomology are better understood as descent statements. Spectral sequences may organize computations, but they play no structural role in the argument.

item.title: Six Functor Formalisms: smoothness and suaveness
item.description: We reinterpret D-smooth morphisms in a six functor formalism via the 2-category of kernel associated to a slice geometry. Using Fourier–Mukai kernels to encode functors, smoothness is characterized by left adjointness at the kernel level, yielding automatic base change compatibility. Suaveness is then obtained by imposing invertibility of the dualizing complex as an additional, independent condition.

item.title: Synthetic category theory and type theory
item.description:
This page aims to explain how type theory can be understood within the framework of synthetic category theory.

The content of this page is derived from my questions to Tashi during the second exercise class and Tashi’s responses. I would like to express my gratitude to Tashi here.

We focus on the following two questions:

  • Question I. How should we understand the notion of isofibration (hereafter referred to as a fibration) in synthetic category theory?
  • Question II. Do we still have a weak factorization system in this context?

Next, we will answer these questions through the lens of type theory and the categorical perspective of synthetic category theory.

item.title: Stable Dold–Kan and Descent
item.description: Unified exposition of the stable Dold–Kan correspondence and its application to descent theory in stable categories.

item.title: About me
item.description:
Ou Liu (刘欧)

I am a master’s student in Mathematics at the University of Regensburg. My primary research interests lie at the intersection of Homotopy Theory and Algebraic Geometry.

Education

2025 – Present
M.Sc. in Mathematics, University of Regensburg

  • Focus: Homotopy Theory, Algebraic Geometry

2021 – 2025
B.Sc. in Mathematics and Applied Mathematics, Shanxi University

  • Thesis: Applications of the six-functor formalism to smooth representation theory
  • Publication:
    Lili Liu, Xi Wang, Ou Liu, et al.
    Valuation and Comparison of the Actual and Optimal Control Strategy in an Emerging Infectious Disease.
